awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A High-sensitivity Beryllium-10 Record from an Ice Core at South Pole
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will acquire measurements of the concentration of beryllium-10 (10Be) from an ice core from the South Pole, Antarctica.  An isotope of the element beryllium, 10Be, is produced in the atmosphere by high-energy protons (cosmic rays) that enter Earth's atmosphere from space.  It is removed from the atmosphere by settling or by scavenging by rain or snowfall.  Hence, concentrations of 10Be in snow at the South Pole reflect the production rate of 10Be in the atmosphere.  Because the rate of production of 10Be over Antarctica depends primarily on the strength of the Sun's magnetic field, measurements of 10Be in the South Pole ice core will provide a record of changes in solar activity.  The South Pole ice core will reach an age of 40,000 years at the bottom.  The project will result in measurements of 10Be at annual resolution for the last 100 years and selected periods in the more distant past, such as the Maunder Minimum, a period during the late 17th century during which no sunspots were observed, or the last glacial cold period, about 20,000 years ago.  A climate model that can simulate the production of 10Be in the atmosphere, it's transport through the atmosphere, and its deposition at the snow surface in Antarctica will be used to aid in using the 10Be data to determine past changes in solar activity from decadal to millennial scale, and in turn to evaluate the role of the Sun in Earth?s climate from a new perspective.

The production of 10Be in Earth's atmosphere results from the spallation of oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere by cosmic rays.  Cosmic ray variations in the high latitudes are primarily modulated by solar variability. Time-series records of 10Be from ice cores are therefore important for deriving variations in solar activity through time, which is fundamental to understanding climate variability. Deposition of 10Be to the ice surface is also influenced by variability in atmospheric circulation and deposition processes, and South Pole is the best available location for minimizing the influence of variable atmospheric circulation on 10Be deposition. To date, only one record of 10Be exists from South Pole; that record is widely used in solar forcing estimates used in climate models, but covers only the last millennium and ends in CE 1982.  We will obtain 10Be concentration measurements in a 1500-m, 40000-year long ice core from the South Pole.  This will extend the existing record both further back in time and forward to the present, providing overlap with the modern instrumental record of solar and climate variability. High resolution (annual to biannual) measurements will be made in targeted areas of interest, including the last 100 years, the Maunder Minimum (CE 1650-1715), and the last glacial maximum. The novel data will be used in conjunction with climate model experiments that incorporate 10Be production, transport, and deposition physics. Together, data and modeling will create an updated record of atmospheric 10Be production and hence of solar activity.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we analyzed the 10Be deposition at South Pole over the Common Era (last 2000 years), and compared the 10Be data from the South Pole Ice core section of the ongoing warm-period (refered to as the Holocene, the last 11,500 years) to 10Be measurements of samples from the last ice-age.

So, why is this important?

The original dream behind measuring 10Be from ice cores is more than 50 years old, it was born when the first polar ice-sheet drilling programs began. 10Be is produced by charged cosmic particles coming from outer space and hitting atoms like oxygen in the upper atmosphere. This atmospheric 10Be production depends on the strength of the sun, that interacts with the geomagnetic field, modulating the influx of the charged cosmic particles. So, the hope was that by measuring 10Be in ice cores from polar ice-sheets, we can reconstruct the strength of the sun in the past, and thus could evaluate its influence on the terrestrial climate.

However, the 10Be ice core experiment turned out to be more complicated, because of variety of complex processes: First, the transport of the 10Be produced high up in the sky downwards through ~ 10 km of atmosphere before it reaches the earth's surface turned out to be highly complex and variable in space and time. Many studies have shown that this transport is strongly influenced by meteorlogic and climate effects that vary locally, 'super-imposing' the direct relation between solar irradiation strength and 10Be production. Locations of the ice core matters! Analytically, 10Be has been hard to measure and required relatively large amounts of the precious ice cores (kg to several 100 g of ice) to reach an analytical precision of ~ 5% or better.

In this project, we made use of the unique position of the South Pole in terms of 10Be transport, and implemented recent advances in 10Be analytics. The modeling experiments in our project make the physical case that at South Pole the 10Be transport from the upper atmosphere to the ice sheet is robust versus even large climate changes, which explains the outstanding quality of the one existing 10Be record from South Pole, produced in the 1990s by the 10Be pioneer Grant Raisbeck and his team. This means that in the South Pole 10Be record, the solar signal is uniquely expressed. In parallel to the modeling, we produced a 10Be record from South Pole covering the last 2000 years. What became immediately apparent in our 10Be record was the stunning reflection of the known periods of 'solar minima', that was reported by early astronomers of the 18th and 19th century, who started to observe sun-spots, a measure of solar activity. They recognized that there were period of very few, or no, sun-spots, that they dubbed 'solar minima'. These periods of directly observed low sun-spot numbers appear very clear and prominent in the South Pole record, and we discovered an early, so far unreport, solar minimum around 800 CE. Finally, the new 10Be record from South Pole extends up to the year 2010. This is important, because it allows for direct comparison of 10Be flux to South Pole and direct solar observations, and in turn for calibration of the currently accepted transfer fuctions.

We then compared the 10Be production record from South Pole to climate reconstructions over the last 2000 years. Please note that the greenhouse gas forcing over these last 2000 years was relatively constant. We found general consistency between our 10Be South Pole record and major climate events over this period, such as the Little Ice Age, or the Roman Warm Period, which might indicate an more important role of solar irradiation changes on Holocene climate variability than previously asssumed.

Finally, we moved the needle of 10Be analyses in ice-cores to a point that we can now measure 10Be in annual or bi-annual resolution with relatively small  samples of 10-15 g of South Pole ice. Alternatively, we could measure 10Be with decadal resolution with 1 g ice samples.

In summary, we are optimistic that our findings will (i) improve the solar irradiation component in climate models, (ii) usher in a new era of 10Be ice core resarch, and most importantly (iii) motivate a new generation of students and early career scientists to join this field. While we included a number of undergraduate and graduate students in this project, the one aspect of this project that was seriously impacted by the pandemic was the Outreach element. Our team is seriously committed to correct this, and include a strong DEI component in future ice core projects. We see the goal to build a better, more inclusive and more diverse, as the most important challenge of all geosciences.
